documentType: Bureau of Prisons internal memorandum and psychological reconstruction report
summary: This is a Bureau of Prisons psychological reconstruction report on the suicide death of inmate Jeffrey Epstein on August 10, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York. The report details his background, legal history, mental health assessments, and the circumstances leading to his death, including a prior incident on July 23, 2019. It concludes with operational recommendations for suicide prevention. This document is part of an internal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) report reviewing the circumstances surrounding Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and death at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. It details numerous procedural failures, documentation inaccuracies, and lapses in protocol related to suicide watch, inmate monitoring, record-keeping, and staff training.

events.title: Florida Guilty Plea
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein entered a non-prosecution agreement and pleaded guilty to one count of Solicitation of Prostitution and one count of Procuring a Person Under the Age of 18 for Prostitution in Florida. He was sentenced to 30 months incarceration and probation.

events.title: Federal Sex Trafficking Charges
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was formally charged with Sex Trafficking Conspiracy and Sex Trafficking in the Southern District of New York, accused of sexually exploiting and abusing minor females over several years.

events.title: Arrest at Teterboro Airport
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was arrested at Teterboro Airport in New Jersey upon his return from Paris, France, and transported to the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York.

events.title: Bail Denial
events.description: Judge Richard M. Berman denied Jeffrey Epstein's request for bail and pretrial release, deeming him a danger and a flight risk.

events.title: First Incident in Cell
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell with a piece of orange cloth around his neck, displaying friction marks. He was placed on suicide watch. He denied it was a suicide attempt and initially claimed his cellmate tried to kill him.

events.title: Court Documents Unsealed
events.description: Approximately 2,000 pages of documents were unsealed, including graphic allegations against Jeffrey Epstein and naming other high-profile figures, including Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at the MCC New York SHU at approximately 6:33 a.m. He was pronounced deceased at a hospital at 7:36 a.m. The report concludes he died by suicide.

events.title: Epstein Found Unresponsive
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at MCC New York with abrasions on his neck and knee. Conflicting reports describe a "string" or "piece of handmade orange cloth" around his neck.

events.title: Epstein on Suicide Watch
events.description: Epstein was placed on suicide watch. During this time, he had an attorney visit lasting approximately 6.5 hours without the required "direct, continuous observation" by BOP staff.

events.title: Extended Attorney Visits During Psychological Observation
events.description: While on Psychological Observation, Epstein had attorney visits totaling over 60 hours across six days. Continuous observation by a dedicated BOP staff member was not maintained as required.

events.title: Epstein Denied Bail
events.description: A judge denied Epstein bail, which the report notes was a "significant disappointment" that likely challenged his ability to adapt to incarceration.

events.title: Unmonitored Telephone Call
events.description: Epstein was escorted to the SHU to place a telephone call. A Unit Manager dialed a number (area code 347) for him. Epstein claimed he was calling his deceased mother. The call was not made on a monitored line.

events.title: Initial Concern for Epstein's Mental State
events.description: Upon arrival at MCC New York, a Facility Assistant observed Epstein as "distraught, sad and a little confused" and emailed staff requesting a psychologist speak with him. Required follow-up actions were not taken.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide on August 10, 2019, while in pretrial custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York.
The reconstruction was severely limited because the FBI had confiscated the original video footage and formal interviews were not conducted to avoid interfering with pending DOJ investigations.
On July 23, 2019, Epstein was found with a cloth around his neck but denied a suicide attempt, claiming his cellmate had tried to kill him. He was placed on suicide watch for 31 hours.
On the night of his death, Epstein was single-celled because his cellmate did not return from court, and staff failed to complete proper 30-minute rounds at 3:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m.

The report notes that on August 9, 2019, the day before his death, approximately 2,000 pages of court documents were unsealed, containing graphic allegations and naming associates like Ghislaine Maxwell.

There were significant inconsistencies in the documentation of the scene when Epstein was found unresponsive on July 23, 2019, with one report mentioning a "string" and another a "piece of handmade orange cloth" around his neck.

Critical procedural failures occurred, including a lack of direct, continuous observation during Epstein's suicide watch and extended attorney visits, and failure to follow up on early concerns about his mental state.

Multiple documentation errors were found: incorrect data in psychology intake forms, inaccurate suicide watch logs that were improperly altered by staff, and inconsistent inmate housing assignments in the SENTRY system.
Epstein was allowed to make an unmonitored telephone call on August 9, 2019, where he claimed to be calling his mother (who died in 2004), with a staff member dialing a number with area code 347.
The report indicates a systemic lack of control and accuracy in record-keeping, including unsecured attorney log books after Epstein's death and incomplete staff training records.
